An earthquake is a move of earth mass
A violently rotating column of air that touches the ground and whips up debris in its path.
A large mass of snow, ice, and rock that suddenly slides down a mountainside.
A large mass of rock, soil, or other debris that slides down a slope.
A severe snowstorm with strong winds and very low visibility.
A violent weather system with strong winds, heavy precipitation, and sometimes thunder and lightning.
A giant wave caused by an underwater earthquake, volcanic eruption, or landslide.
An overflow of water that submerges land that is usually dry.
An uncontrolled event at an industrial facility that can cause harm to people, property, or the environment.
A mountain that erupts, spewing out lava, ash, and gas.
A period of abnormally hot weather that can last for days or even weeks.
An uncontrolled fire in nature that spreads quickly and can cause extensive damage to forests, homes, and property.
An uncontrolled release of radioactive material/hazardous chemicals from a plants or industries, which can have devastating consequences for human health and the environment.

Seek immediate shelter in a basement, storm cellar, or interior room on the lowest floor away from windows and doors. If no safe room is available, lie flat in a ditch and cover your head and neck with your arms.
Drop, cover, and hold on. Drop to the ground, take cover under a sturdy desk or table, and hold on until the shaking stops. Stay away from windows, mirrors, and hanging objects.
If caught in an avalanche path, try to move to the side of the slope and hold onto something sturdy. If escape is impossible, curl up in a ball and protect your head and neck with your arms.
Evacuate the area immediately if a landslide is imminent. Do not cross moving debris or enter unstable areas.
Stay indoors where it is warm and avoid unnecessary travel. Dress warmly in layers if you must go outside. Stay informed about weather updates and road closures.
Seek shelter in a sturdy building away from windows and doors. Close all windows and shutters. Do not drive through flooded areas.
Evacuate to higher ground immediately if a tsunami warning is issued. Do not wait for further instructions.
Evacuate the area immediately if flooding is imminent. Do not drive through flooded roads or attempt to walk through floodwaters. Follow instructions from emergency officials.
Follow instructions from emergency responders and stay away from the affected area. Stay informed about updates and potential evacuations.
Follow evacuation orders and avoid areas downwind of the volcano. Wear protective clothing and mask if outdoors due to ashfall.
Stay cool and hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids and avoiding strenuous activity. Stay in air-conditioned spaces as much as possible. Check on vulnerable individuals like children and the elderly.
Evacuate immediately if instructed by authorities. If unable to evacuate, close windows and doors and create a defensible space around your home. Follow official updates and instructions.

Follow instructions from emergency personnel. Seek shelter indoors and close all windows and doors. Cover exposed skin and hair. Evacuate if instructed. Stay informed about the situation and potential health risks.
